reviewText:
Metroid lite.  Scratches that upgrade-based progression itch, but isn't very substantial.

Gamefeel is pretty nice, but there's no variable jump height and you can't move while aiming up, which are both annoying.  Difficulty felt just right to me.  Like Super Metroid, exploration is generally fairly easy, with moderate difficulty bumps for boss fights.

Weapon customization feels kinda pointless to me.  Using anything other than the two DPS stats just seems like a waste.  You also have to enter the menu to toggle your super blasty gun, and to swap gun stat presets.  Why not use LB and back/select for these?

Exploration is pretty simplistic.  Four small, fairly straightforward planets that you move between via a glorified level select screen.  Keeps up the pace, but really limits the trailblazer feel that makes Metroid so satisfying.

Overall it's fun and well put together, but honestly kinda forgettable.  Grab it on sale and play through it in an afternoon if you're into Metroid.

reviewText:
Xenodrifter is a 2D watered down metroid clone- you know the kind. Navigate mazes, get power-ups to access new areas, fight evil space monsters, and backtracking galore. Xenodrifter straddles the gorge with one foot on the side of neat ideas with the other firmly planted in unnecessary tedium. The major power-up and mechanical theme is lifted from an older title Renagade Kid worked on called Mutant Mudds, where the protagonist can warp from foreground to background to traverse the world. Another major feature is how you can customize the gun- the hero's main form of attack. Want the bullets to weave through the air? There's an upgrade for that. Faster Bullets? Got it. Spray and pray? Right here. You can allocate points to make your gun as “wavy” or “fast” as you like. As you progress through the game, the more of these upgrade points you find and the crazier your custom gun becomes.

However, the gameplay is fairly dull. The stages have bleak layouts with no real threats besides the odd off-screen enemy ramming you. The game just has that “autopilot” feel. Jump up ledges, stand still to shoot the bouncing baddy, move on. No real hazards, interesting enemies, or challenging puzzles. The bosses are the same creature with different colors and more attack actions. This visually makes bosses anti-climatic and their patterns obvious.  Oddly, the game feature few checkpoints- only one at the start of the stage and when you face the planet boss. This can lead to some false difficulty and more tedium as you face the same enemies, the same layout, with the same stage all over again from the beginning if you get nixed. Snore.

If you absolutely enjoy these types of 2D action-adventure games then you've played much better and far worse. Xendrifter is in the middle- it has good bullet points to pique your interest, but nothing engaging to make you stay. If your interested in playing one of these types of games, Xenodrfter is not a good first choice. A nice second just to see what an “everyday” metroid-clone feels like.

A sale, coupon, or bundle item- don't get it full price.

This is a short metroidvania. Graphics aren't bad if you like them pixels, and it plays okay, but it had too many problems for me to recommend it.

In no certain order, here they are:

3. At some point you get a sort of new weapon (usually you upgrade your basic weapon), but it's mostly for breaking barriers and not general combat. However to switch weapons you need to go into the menu to turn the special weapon on or off, even though this could have easily been relegated to a button.

Now I bought it when it was really cheap, so I don't feel cheated out or anything, but it's certainly not worth full price ($9.99).

To be fair though, it is fun to use the abilities you pick up as you play the game. If only the planets weren't so small so that you could have even more fun moving around...

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a neat little Metroid-like. The abilities are unique and used to good effect with some inventive environment-traversal tricks. I liked the setup of moving between four different planets instead of having four different areas interconnected on the same planet. The weapon-upgrading system is excellent; being able to experiment with different weapon types by redistributing your upgrade points at any time is a great touch.

The game has its weak points, but they're more on the order of minor gripes than major flaws. At first I didn't like the way my character jumped (always reaching maximum height instead of varying depending on how hard I pressed), but I got used to it. You fight the same boss character repeatedly, which may be a little tedious, but the fight changes over time, and its recurrence plays a role in the (admittedly thin) story. I really wish I could have cycled through weapons without going to the pause screen; the left and right triggers on my controller were just begging to be used. I also wish I could have used the thumbstick for movement, because the absolute worst part of this game was my 360 controller's d-pad.

Xeodrifter doesn't overstay its welcome; my six-hour playtime is quite a bit longer than necessary because I spent some time jumping against every wall I could, trying to find a couple of secret passages that were eluding me. But despite it being a little on the short side, it felt like the right length to me, and made for a nice bite-sized weekend diversion. I have a big soft spot for Metroidvanias in general, so I'm predisposed to giving a thumbs-up here, but I found a lot to like.

reviewText:
Simply put: I adore this game; It hits all the right notes of Metroid nostalgia from beginning to end.

You can check out my impressions and a playthrough in video format here, or read more below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WwN--i1PrQ

Xeodrifter is a small game, but one that excels at what it sets out to do.  Xeodrifter hearkens back to the feelings you get playing Metroid, Metroid II, and Super Metroid, borrowing elements from all 3 of those games with many new twists and mechanics of its own.  The art, sound, and music are great, the controls are fluid and responsive.

The game takes place across 4 planets for you to explore and fight your way through, gathering power-ups along the way.

Power-ups come in two formats: Health/Gun points that increase your total health or allow for customizing your weapon, and progression-based upgrades from bosses that allow you to explore new areas and bypass obstacles.

Bosses follow a very Metroid II-esque format, in that each boss builds on the previous one in a mechanical evolution style.

While yes, the game is short at around 2.5-3 hours for an experienced gamer, it's an incredibly enjoyable experience.  I personally felt it was well worth it at the full $10 price-point, but for those that are wary I would absolutely pick it up if it's ever on sale, you'd be doing yourself a disservice to pass it by!

reviewText:
A pretty cool little Metroidvania from the Mutant Mudds devs. I joked on Twitter that this is a Muddtroidvania, and it really is, with the background/foreground switching coming into play. The game is quasi-linear in that you can theoretically go to any of the four planets at any time, but you'll run into natural barriers demanding you go elsewhere to get the ability you need. The gun upgrade system is clever in that it lets you put points into any stat that you please so that you can get your preferred mode of fire.

It's rather challenging in part because the only checkpoints are before boss fights, so you need to be careful while exploring the worlds, as if you die, you can lose a lot of found items. It's hardly impossible, but it feels like it wouldn't be less enjoyable if the checkpoints were more generous.

The game was clearly built for the 3DS first, as it's got VERY chunky pixels. Not that it's a bad thing or that it looks ugly, it just looks like a handheld game blown up – which it is! You'll need to alt-enter to use fullscreen, and the options for gamepads and the like are only in windowed mode. 360 controllers work, DirectInput controllers should as well through the configuration, but as always, YMMV. I do wish that it was possible to use the triggers to switch weapon layouts, as particularly when fighting bosses I found myself switching weapons tactically.

I certainly enjoyed my time with this, it won't replace Super Metroid or Symphony of the Night in the canon of Metroidvanias, but it compelled me to beat it in short order, and that's worthy of my stamp of approval.

reviewText:
Liked the game, has an old school metroid vibe to it, but it suffers two flaws in my opinion:

It's too short and the bosses are all the same with incremental patterns (i.e. the second boss has all the patterns of the first plus some new ones, the third boss has all of the patterns from before and his own, etc...)

The modular weapon upgrades that one can change at wish is great, but there is never enough game to allow for multiple combinations try outs. It just comes down to maximizing damage and then fire rate to increase DPS.

What sentiment do I retain from playing this? Slight disappointment, as it is too good a game to be this short.

If the difficulty would have been extreme then I would understood. Kinda like VVVVVVVV being short and it not bothering me as much. But the game is fairly easy and straight forward. There's no back tracking unless you want to catch some extras and even that is not something that is going to make me go back.

For less than two euros I guess I could recommend it, but paying more and becoming disappointed of not having enough is just not worth it. As someone else already pointed out in a review. As soon as one is having fun, the game just ends. There is no time nor new environments in which to test the new found abilities for a satisfactory time.

Sum up:
+Graphics: nice and neat old retro pixel art (loved it)
+Gameplay: Nervous, adaptive, not frustrating, if it's game over there is only oneself to blame, abilities are well thought and fun to use, modular upgrades mechanic is a nice idea
+Sound effects: great chip tune shooting and enemy sounds
+/-Music: Good chip tune but not enough variety
+/-Environments: Some are better than others, too linear though with 4 planets having one or two ability focused design. Maybe one big environment would have made for more backtracking and the metroidvaniaesque feel
-Enemies: too little different enemies overall, varied ones could have required different upgrade builds, bosses are a joke of code copy pasting and color changing, could have used more creativity
--Lifetime: too short for a good game, makes us want more

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CsU6pvuuosY

Take a Metroid game, spread it across four different planets, and make it bite-sized, and you have Xeodrifter by Renegade Kid.

What makes Xeodrifter cool and separates it from other Metroidvanias is its abilities, one of which borrows from their back catalog. There's no other Metroid-like game where your character can turn into a submarine, or can switch between foreground and background layers. The plane shifting allows for great map design that often sneaks secrets right past you in plain sight. Just pay attention you goof!

The weapons system allows you to spend (and respec) points on different attributes, from rate of fire to power to... inaccuracy? That one's a little weird. You also get to store three different presets to suit whatever playstyle you feel like. Plus you get a charge shot, Mega Man X-style, which can help take out some of the tankier enemies (like that BAT. THAT STUPID BAT, WHY. GO TO HELL, BAT).

It looks good, the music is great, it's compact and doesn't overstay its welcome, the only downside is that the boss is recycled over and over (but it does gain new attack patterns each time). Good game to buy in a sale, a fun little title.

*IMPORTANT, IT'S A GOOD GAME BUT WORTH 3-5, WOULD NOT RECOMMEND AT NORMAL $10 PRICE!*

This is a really charming game, and deffinitely worth the price. yes it's short, but it's challenging and has a couple of unique mechanics (which i won't spoil due to the length of the game)

a couple of things i really appreciate are the nature of the upgrades. you earn weapon upgrades, which serve as points for you to spend on a kind of skill tree. the devs really went out of their way to give you freedom with these skill trees:

-spending points is not permenant you can change things at a moments notice
-you have skill sets, so you can switch between two or even three play styles very easily

little touches like these make this game an A-list for me.

also, there are no checkpoints in the game, except for right before bosses, making the levels challenging, but completely cutting out the frustration should you die at the boss, since you spawn outside and can try again.

the graphics are actually really nice. at first glance they might appear to be a cheap 8-bit look to shorten dev time, but actually there's a lot of thought given to aesthetic and theme, each enviornment feels very different and vibrant.

the one nit-pick i might have is with the boss, instead of fighting several different bosses, you fight the same boss several times, but with new attack patterns. now that being said, it really works for the game and gives it a great progression in difficulty, but it still felt kind of tedious seeing the same boss over and over.

great game, buy it, perfect friday night time-waster.

reviewText:
Picked this up for about $4 on the latest Digital Devolver sale.

Pros:
Tight, responsive controls.
The in-game map is a solid clone of Super Metroid's map.
The weapon upgrade system encourages experimentation and has multiple setups so you can quickly swap between the three options depending on the situation.
The game doesn't outstay its welcome. If doubled in length, the game would have worn thin.

Cons:
No controls for cycling weapons and solar flare, requiring the player to access the menu to change.
Two of the weapon upgrades are pretty useless. The game was completeable without shot speed or spread. Wave, Power, and rapid fire were sufficient.
Bosses are palette swaps, each adding on one new ability along with the previous bosses.
The four worlds are small, and nondistinct outside of color.
Enemies are simple, and mostly uninteresting.
The game is completable in part of an afternoon. A slightly longer end-game to play with all of the acquired abilities in concert would have been welcome.

reviewText:
I picked this up on a whim (75% off), and was pleased with it. I don't really care for elaborate reviews, so I'll keep it simple.

THE GOOD:
-The soundtrack is awesome. These feel like tunes that would've been stuck in my head from 1991.
-The weapon upgrade system is neat. It allows you to really tailor your approach.
-The gameplay. This is pretty solid Metroidvania.
-Linear difficulty curve. For an afternoon play, I got enough challenging spots without getting frustrated.

THE NOT-SO-GOOD:
-The weapon upgrade system. 3 of your 5 upgrades are worthless. Faster projectiles, maybe. But the angled shots? Why bother. Wave shot was helpful for exactly 1 enemy in the game.
-Storyline. There isn't one.
-The backtracking. Metroidvania-style games are notorious for this. However, the upgrades you get are used in every single level. So it's essentially trial-and-error to find the level that you can progress the furthest in with the set of upgrades you have.
-The same creature is used for every single boss fight. Enemies are recycled in every single level.
-The levels look different, but ultimately play out exactly the same.
-The game is very short. I registered 4.9 hours, and that's only because I spent a good chunk of that making dinner and watching TV with my girlfriend.
-A lot of wasted potential.

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a neat and effective little metroid-vania style exploration-based platformer. The art is very clean and the colour palette is vibrant. The game runs smoothly and doesn't waste any time holding your hand, it just lets you get on with it.

The controls are very satisfying once you've unlocked the full moveset and mastered them and the world is gated in a quite satisfying manner, as the abilities you obtain allow you to over come the various obstacles of the geography in an organic way. Non of the usual ice-beam unlocks white doors, super missile unlocks green, gamey approach here.

As others have mentioned, the game is quite short, I have 6.5 hours logged and have completed the game with every achievement unlocked. The first 6 hours were spent on the initial play through and locating all the unpgrades, with the rest spent on a speed run.

If you're not sure $10/£7 is good enough value for 6+ hours of gameplay then wait for a sale; the game received a 75% discount during the 2015 Steam Summer Sale, so will probably be heavily discounted in the future.

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a short but sweet Metroid-like game where the player must explore 4 unique planets to find new abilities and a number of power-ups in order to find their way home. Taking a page out of Metroid Fusion the map is separated into 4 different sections with a hub (the players ship) rather than the Super Metroid approach of a single interconnected world. Each of these levels has a number of routes which can be opened with new abilities and contain power-ups to give the player an easier time.

Xeodrifter controls rather well but does suffer from a slightly floaty feel in regards to the movement. Having only used an Xbox controller I found it intuitive but would probably advise against using a keyboard.

One of the power-ups the player can find is a Gun Mod. Each of these is a single point which can be used to customize the way your weapon functions. By mixing and matching these point (which can be refunded and re-added at any point) you will be able to increase the damage, firing rate and spread or even make the bullets fire in a sine wave. You can also save 3 varieties of firing modes for quick use in the future.

The planets are filled with a wide array of beasts which will try and impede your progress, many of which have attack patterns players which have experienced a Metroid game will recognize. All of them have different ways of hindering the player and there was rarely a time I found myself annoyed at their placement in the world.

The downside to this game is of course its length, you can probably beat this game in well under 3 hours. There is also only a single boss to battle. However each time you fight it there is a new move or 2 added to its library, making it slightly more difficult. Another variety of boss or two would have helped keep it fresh though.
A final complaint is the construction of the fourth world. While all of the others have a few branching or looping paths this one is almost entirely linear. This planet just doesn't seem to have had the same attention put into its creation which is a bit of a shame.

Overall anyone who is a fan of Metroid-like platform games should definitely check this one out and not be put off by the short playtime provided. Xeodrifter, while short, does not overstay its welcome and the abilities you collect from the bosses make revisiting old locations for new gear a joy.

I was immediately interested in this game when I saw it was released by the same people who made Mutant Mudds. After watching the trailer for Xeodrifter, I was hoping to play a well-crafted action adventure game that hearkened back to the days of Metroid and Blaster Master. I'm happy to say that is exactly what I got.

The premise of Xeodrifter is incredibly simple: your ship needs a new warp core and unless you want to be left stranded out in the depths of space forever, your only option is to explore four nearby planets and seach for a new core. As you explore each planet, you'll slowly uncover a plethora of health and weapon upgrades, as well as new abilties to help you on your way (rocket jump, submarine, etc.) There is no text in the game and that's okay: it helps immerse the player in the atmosphere of the game.

That being said, the gameplay pulls through and makes Xeodrifter a fun play. While the controls are slightly floaty, the game moves at a nice pace. You have a selection of upgrades to choose from in upgrading your energy shot which allows for a little customization. As you uncover more and more upgrades, the difficulty of the game slowly ramps along with your progression. This, and the integration of your new abilties, keeps Xeodrifter from becoming boring or repetitive; as the game is only a few short hours, it doesn't bog itself down or drag itself out.

So. The graphics are colorful, the music is fantastic, and it plays great. It covers all the bases well. Buy it. If you're fan of classic Metroid action/exploration, you owe it to yourself to get this.

reviewText:
I originally wrote a review of this that was brief and a bit hasty. I stand by my complaint, but I feel I can give it a bit more direction.

The downsides:
* The jump height is fixed. No feathering to shoot the badies. This is a gross oversight and not in line with classic NES style.
* Slop in the controls. Not much, but enough to be frustrating. Platforming will just make you angry at the start.
* The very first boss is absolutley unforgiving. They are all hard, but the first one is so outright unfair that it led to my initial bad review.
* Boss methods are sometimes unclear, leaving you to do random things until something inexplicably changes. Good luck surviving through this. Thankfully, most of the boss behavior is random so he may not even do it next round.
* The character's power is quadratic. As you gain more Health and more Gun, you quickly find the challenge taper off.
* Some enemies are tedious to kill, not actually hard. There will be a pattern to learn, but do I really need to do it ten times to kill one thing?

The upsides:
* Challenging, but doable. Bosses require reflexes and patience. It's a difficult mix to master.
* Graphics are fantastic. It feels like the love child of my NES favorites Blaster Master and Metroid.
* Music is great. (I'm biased, there's a nod to David Bowie on the soundtrack. Instant win.)

So with more negative points than positive ones, why am I changing this to recommend? Firstly, because there is no neutral, which is what I really feel it should be. This game is not for everyone, chiefly because the challenge is just too high at the start. With limited space to explore until you down that first boss, the gameplay value becomes about 5 minutes if you cannot proceed.

A couple of things that would fix it:
* Feathering. Many enemies need a mini-jump to line up the shot. Let us control our jumps. This actually matters.
* Difficulty setting. A novice mode in which the bosses movements aren't quite so quick. Also opens the door for hard (bosses have twice the HP) and nightmare (bosses have twice the HP and faster reaction times). Think about it.

In the end, I am recommending the game. It's just a weak recommendation, with the caveat that if you are really easily frustrated, you might want to sit this one out (at least until it has a difficulty option).

reviewText:
Xenodrifter is a 2D watered down metroid clone- you know the kind. Navigate mazes, get power-ups to access new areas, fight evil space monsters, and backtracking galore. Xenodrifter straddles the gorge with one foot on the side of neat ideas with the other firmly planted in unnecessary tedium. The major power-up and mechanical theme is lifted from an older title Renagade Kid worked on called Mutant Mudds, where the protagonist can warp from foreground to background to traverse the world. Another major feature is how you can customize the gun- the hero's main form of attack. Want the bullets to weave through the air? There's an upgrade for that. Faster Bullets? Got it. Spray and pray? Right here. You can allocate points to make your gun as “wavy” or “fast” as you like. As you progress through the game, the more of these upgrade points you find and the crazier your custom gun becomes.

However, the gameplay is fairly dull. The stages have bleak layouts with no real threats besides the odd off-screen enemy ramming you. The game just has that “autopilot” feel. Jump up ledges, stand still to shoot the bouncing baddy, move on. No real hazards, interesting enemies, or challenging puzzles. The bosses are the same creature with different colors and more attack actions. This visually makes bosses anti-climatic and their patterns obvious.  Oddly, the game feature few checkpoints- only one at the start of the stage and when you face the planet boss. This can lead to some false difficulty and more tedium as you face the same enemies, the same layout, with the same stage all over again from the beginning if you get nixed. Snore.

If you absolutely enjoy these types of 2D action-adventure games then you've played much better and far worse. Xendrifter is in the middle- it has good bullet points to pique your interest, but nothing engaging to make you stay. If your interested in playing one of these types of games, Xenodrfter is not a good first choice. A nice second just to see what an “everyday” metroid-clone feels like.

A sale, coupon, or bundle item- don't get it full price.

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a neat little Metroid-like. The abilities are unique and used to good effect with some inventive environment-traversal tricks. I liked the setup of moving between four different planets instead of having four different areas interconnected on the same planet. The weapon-upgrading system is excellent; being able to experiment with different weapon types by redistributing your upgrade points at any time is a great touch.

The game has its weak points, but they're more on the order of minor gripes than major flaws. At first I didn't like the way my character jumped (always reaching maximum height instead of varying depending on how hard I pressed), but I got used to it. You fight the same boss character repeatedly, which may be a little tedious, but the fight changes over time, and its recurrence plays a role in the (admittedly thin) story. I really wish I could have cycled through weapons without going to the pause screen; the left and right triggers on my controller were just begging to be used. I also wish I could have used the thumbstick for movement, because the absolute worst part of this game was my 360 controller's d-pad.

Xeodrifter doesn't overstay its welcome; my six-hour playtime is quite a bit longer than necessary because I spent some time jumping against every wall I could, trying to find a couple of secret passages that were eluding me. But despite it being a little on the short side, it felt like the right length to me, and made for a nice bite-sized weekend diversion. I have a big soft spot for Metroidvanias in general, so I'm predisposed to giving a thumbs-up here, but I found a lot to like.

Simply put: I adore this game; It hits all the right notes of Metroid nostalgia from beginning to end.

You can check out my impressions and a playthrough in video format here, or read more below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WwN--i1PrQ

Xeodrifter is a small game, but one that excels at what it sets out to do.  Xeodrifter hearkens back to the feelings you get playing Metroid, Metroid II, and Super Metroid, borrowing elements from all 3 of those games with many new twists and mechanics of its own.  The art, sound, and music are great, the controls are fluid and responsive.

The game takes place across 4 planets for you to explore and fight your way through, gathering power-ups along the way.

Power-ups come in two formats: Health/Gun points that increase your total health or allow for customizing your weapon, and progression-based upgrades from bosses that allow you to explore new areas and bypass obstacles.

Bosses follow a very Metroid II-esque format, in that each boss builds on the previous one in a mechanical evolution style.

While yes, the game is short at around 2.5-3 hours for an experienced gamer, it's an incredibly enjoyable experience.  I personally felt it was well worth it at the full $10 price-point, but for those that are wary I would absolutely pick it up if it's ever on sale, you'd be doing yourself a disservice to pass it by!

reviewText:
A pretty cool little Metroidvania from the Mutant Mudds devs. I joked on Twitter that this is a Muddtroidvania, and it really is, with the background/foreground switching coming into play. The game is quasi-linear in that you can theoretically go to any of the four planets at any time, but you'll run into natural barriers demanding you go elsewhere to get the ability you need. The gun upgrade system is clever in that it lets you put points into any stat that you please so that you can get your preferred mode of fire.

It's rather challenging in part because the only checkpoints are before boss fights, so you need to be careful while exploring the worlds, as if you die, you can lose a lot of found items. It's hardly impossible, but it feels like it wouldn't be less enjoyable if the checkpoints were more generous.

The game was clearly built for the 3DS first, as it's got VERY chunky pixels. Not that it's a bad thing or that it looks ugly, it just looks like a handheld game blown up – which it is! You'll need to alt-enter to use fullscreen, and the options for gamepads and the like are only in windowed mode. 360 controllers work, DirectInput controllers should as well through the configuration, but as always, YMMV. I do wish that it was possible to use the triggers to switch weapon layouts, as particularly when fighting bosses I found myself switching weapons tactically.

I certainly enjoyed my time with this, it won't replace Super Metroid or Symphony of the Night in the canon of Metroidvanias, but it compelled me to beat it in short order, and that's worthy of my stamp of approval.

reviewText:
Liked the game, has an old school metroid vibe to it, but it suffers two flaws in my opinion:

It's too short and the bosses are all the same with incremental patterns (i.e. the second boss has all the patterns of the first plus some new ones, the third boss has all of the patterns from before and his own, etc...)

The modular weapon upgrades that one can change at wish is great, but there is never enough game to allow for multiple combinations try outs. It just comes down to maximizing damage and then fire rate to increase DPS.

What sentiment do I retain from playing this? Slight disappointment, as it is too good a game to be this short.

If the difficulty would have been extreme then I would understood. Kinda like VVVVVVVV being short and it not bothering me as much. But the game is fairly easy and straight forward. There's no back tracking unless you want to catch some extras and even that is not something that is going to make me go back.

For less than two euros I guess I could recommend it, but paying more and becoming disappointed of not having enough is just not worth it. As someone else already pointed out in a review. As soon as one is having fun, the game just ends. There is no time nor new environments in which to test the new found abilities for a satisfactory time.

Sum up:
+Graphics: nice and neat old retro pixel art (loved it)
+Gameplay: Nervous, adaptive, not frustrating, if it's game over there is only oneself to blame, abilities are well thought and fun to use, modular upgrades mechanic is a nice idea
+Sound effects: great chip tune shooting and enemy sounds
+/-Music: Good chip tune but not enough variety
+/-Environments: Some are better than others, too linear though with 4 planets having one or two ability focused design. Maybe one big environment would have made for more backtracking and the metroidvaniaesque feel
-Enemies: too little different enemies overall, varied ones could have required different upgrade builds, bosses are a joke of code copy pasting and color changing, could have used more creativity
--Lifetime: too short for a good game, makes us want more

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CsU6pvuuosY

Take a Metroid game, spread it across four different planets, and make it bite-sized, and you have Xeodrifter by Renegade Kid.

What makes Xeodrifter cool and separates it from other Metroidvanias is its abilities, one of which borrows from their back catalog. There's no other Metroid-like game where your character can turn into a submarine, or can switch between foreground and background layers. The plane shifting allows for great map design that often sneaks secrets right past you in plain sight. Just pay attention you goof!

The weapons system allows you to spend (and respec) points on different attributes, from rate of fire to power to... inaccuracy? That one's a little weird. You also get to store three different presets to suit whatever playstyle you feel like. Plus you get a charge shot, Mega Man X-style, which can help take out some of the tankier enemies (like that BAT. THAT STUPID BAT, WHY. GO TO HELL, BAT).

It looks good, the music is great, it's compact and doesn't overstay its welcome, the only downside is that the boss is recycled over and over (but it does gain new attack patterns each time). Good game to buy in a sale, a fun little title.

Xeodrifter is a Metroidvania for the 3DS that got ported to Steam.  It's pretty damn good too, but extremely short in under 4 hours to beat.  The game offers hidden weapon upgrades, hidden health upgrades and the power ups you need to get to new areas are only provided from defeated bosses.  Speaking of bosses that's this games only weak point (minus the length of course).  There's only ONE boss throughout the entire game, but you fight this ONE boss 10 times or so.  Everytime you meet up with this guy he just gets a little tougher each time.

One really GREAT concept is the jumping back and forth between the foreground and the background.  I'm not sure if I've ever did that in a game before.  Either way, it was fun to do and a welcome edition for Metroidvania's that I'm hoping makes it to others games in the genre.

If you enjoy fun gameplay, a great soundtrack and Metroidvania style gameplay this game is for you.  A tad bit on the short side so grab it on sale to negate buying remorse.  And always make sure to check for hidden rooms through false walls!  ;)

This is a really charming game, and deffinitely worth the price. yes it's short, but it's challenging and has a couple of unique mechanics (which i won't spoil due to the length of the game)

a couple of things i really appreciate are the nature of the upgrades. you earn weapon upgrades, which serve as points for you to spend on a kind of skill tree. the devs really went out of their way to give you freedom with these skill trees:

-spending points is not permenant you can change things at a moments notice
-you have skill sets, so you can switch between two or even three play styles very easily

little touches like these make this game an A-list for me.

also, there are no checkpoints in the game, except for right before bosses, making the levels challenging, but completely cutting out the frustration should you die at the boss, since you spawn outside and can try again.

the graphics are actually really nice. at first glance they might appear to be a cheap 8-bit look to shorten dev time, but actually there's a lot of thought given to aesthetic and theme, each enviornment feels very different and vibrant.

the one nit-pick i might have is with the boss, instead of fighting several different bosses, you fight the same boss several times, but with new attack patterns. now that being said, it really works for the game and gives it a great progression in difficulty, but it still felt kind of tedious seeing the same boss over and over.

great game, buy it, perfect friday night time-waster.

reviewText:
I picked this up on a whim (75% off), and was pleased with it. I don't really care for elaborate reviews, so I'll keep it simple.

THE GOOD:
-The soundtrack is awesome. These feel like tunes that would've been stuck in my head from 1991.
-The weapon upgrade system is neat. It allows you to really tailor your approach.
-The gameplay. This is pretty solid Metroidvania.
-Linear difficulty curve. For an afternoon play, I got enough challenging spots without getting frustrated.

THE NOT-SO-GOOD:
-The weapon upgrade system. 3 of your 5 upgrades are worthless. Faster projectiles, maybe. But the angled shots? Why bother. Wave shot was helpful for exactly 1 enemy in the game.
-Storyline. There isn't one.
-The backtracking. Metroidvania-style games are notorious for this. However, the upgrades you get are used in every single level. So it's essentially trial-and-error to find the level that you can progress the furthest in with the set of upgrades you have.
-The same creature is used for every single boss fight. Enemies are recycled in every single level.
-The levels look different, but ultimately play out exactly the same.
-The game is very short. I registered 4.9 hours, and that's only because I spent a good chunk of that making dinner and watching TV with my girlfriend.
-A lot of wasted potential.

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a neat and effective little metroid-vania style exploration-based platformer. The art is very clean and the colour palette is vibrant. The game runs smoothly and doesn't waste any time holding your hand, it just lets you get on with it.

The controls are very satisfying once you've unlocked the full moveset and mastered them and the world is gated in a quite satisfying manner, as the abilities you obtain allow you to over come the various obstacles of the geography in an organic way. Non of the usual ice-beam unlocks white doors, super missile unlocks green, gamey approach here.

As others have mentioned, the game is quite short, I have 6.5 hours logged and have completed the game with every achievement unlocked. The first 6 hours were spent on the initial play through and locating all the unpgrades, with the rest spent on a speed run.

If you're not sure $10/£7 is good enough value for 6+ hours of gameplay then wait for a sale; the game received a 75% discount during the 2015 Steam Summer Sale, so will probably be heavily discounted in the future.

reviewText:
Xeodrifter is a short but sweet Metroid-like game where the player must explore 4 unique planets to find new abilities and a number of power-ups in order to find their way home. Taking a page out of Metroid Fusion the map is separated into 4 different sections with a hub (the players ship) rather than the Super Metroid approach of a single interconnected world. Each of these levels has a number of routes which can be opened with new abilities and contain power-ups to give the player an easier time.

Xeodrifter controls rather well but does suffer from a slightly floaty feel in regards to the movement. Having only used an Xbox controller I found it intuitive but would probably advise against using a keyboard.

One of the power-ups the player can find is a Gun Mod. Each of these is a single point which can be used to customize the way your weapon functions. By mixing and matching these point (which can be refunded and re-added at any point) you will be able to increase the damage, firing rate and spread or even make the bullets fire in a sine wave. You can also save 3 varieties of firing modes for quick use in the future.

The planets are filled with a wide array of beasts which will try and impede your progress, many of which have attack patterns players which have experienced a Metroid game will recognize. All of them have different ways of hindering the player and there was rarely a time I found myself annoyed at their placement in the world.

The downside to this game is of course its length, you can probably beat this game in well under 3 hours. There is also only a single boss to battle. However each time you fight it there is a new move or 2 added to its library, making it slightly more difficult. Another variety of boss or two would have helped keep it fresh though.
A final complaint is the construction of the fourth world. While all of the others have a few branching or looping paths this one is almost entirely linear. This planet just doesn't seem to have had the same attention put into its creation which is a bit of a shame.

Overall anyone who is a fan of Metroid-like platform games should definitely check this one out and not be put off by the short playtime provided. Xeodrifter, while short, does not overstay its welcome and the abilities you collect from the bosses make revisiting old locations for new gear a joy.

reviewText:
I was immediately interested in this game when I saw it was released by the same people who made Mutant Mudds. After watching the trailer for Xeodrifter, I was hoping to play a well-crafted action adventure game that hearkened back to the days of Metroid and Blaster Master. I'm happy to say that is exactly what I got.

The premise of Xeodrifter is incredibly simple: your ship needs a new warp core and unless you want to be left stranded out in the depths of space forever, your only option is to explore four nearby planets and seach for a new core. As you explore each planet, you'll slowly uncover a plethora of health and weapon upgrades, as well as new abilties to help you on your way (rocket jump, submarine, etc.) There is no text in the game and that's okay: it helps immerse the player in the atmosphere of the game.

That being said, the gameplay pulls through and makes Xeodrifter a fun play. While the controls are slightly floaty, the game moves at a nice pace. You have a selection of upgrades to choose from in upgrading your energy shot which allows for a little customization. As you uncover more and more upgrades, the difficulty of the game slowly ramps along with your progression. This, and the integration of your new abilties, keeps Xeodrifter from becoming boring or repetitive; as the game is only a few short hours, it doesn't bog itself down or drag itself out.

So. The graphics are colorful, the music is fantastic, and it plays great. It covers all the bases well. Buy it. If you're fan of classic Metroid action/exploration, you owe it to yourself to get this.

reviewText:
I originally wrote a review of this that was brief and a bit hasty. I stand by my complaint, but I feel I can give it a bit more direction.

The downsides:
* The jump height is fixed. No feathering to shoot the badies. This is a gross oversight and not in line with classic NES style.
* Slop in the controls. Not much, but enough to be frustrating. Platforming will just make you angry at the start.
* The very first boss is absolutley unforgiving. They are all hard, but the first one is so outright unfair that it led to my initial bad review.
* Boss methods are sometimes unclear, leaving you to do random things until something inexplicably changes. Good luck surviving through this. Thankfully, most of the boss behavior is random so he may not even do it next round.
* The character's power is quadratic. As you gain more Health and more Gun, you quickly find the challenge taper off.
* Some enemies are tedious to kill, not actually hard. There will be a pattern to learn, but do I really need to do it ten times to kill one thing?

The upsides:
* Challenging, but doable. Bosses require reflexes and patience. It's a difficult mix to master.
* Graphics are fantastic. It feels like the love child of my NES favorites Blaster Master and Metroid.
* Music is great. (I'm biased, there's a nod to David Bowie on the soundtrack. Instant win.)

So with more negative points than positive ones, why am I changing this to recommend? Firstly, because there is no neutral, which is what I really feel it should be. This game is not for everyone, chiefly because the challenge is just too high at the start. With limited space to explore until you down that first boss, the gameplay value becomes about 5 minutes if you cannot proceed.

A couple of things that would fix it:
* Feathering. Many enemies need a mini-jump to line up the shot. Let us control our jumps. This actually matters.
* Difficulty setting. A novice mode in which the bosses movements aren't quite so quick. Also opens the door for hard (bosses have twice the HP) and nightmare (bosses have twice the HP and faster reaction times). Think about it.

In the end, I am recommending the game. It's just a weak recommendation, with the caveat that if you are really easily frustrated, you might want to sit this one out (at least until it has a difficulty option).
